basics.name: Adam Kariv
basics.summary:
If it's software related, I can probably do it.

Specialties: 
- Software design of complex systems (esp. embedded systems, large scale distributed systems)
- Excellent knowledge of Python, C, C++, Javascript
- Operating systems concepts & internals (Linux & Android)
- Web application design, both frontend development and large scale distributed backends
- Telecom (Mobile and Fixed), VoIP, IP and other communication protocols
- Finding simple solutions for complex problems

work.summary:
At Screenovate we develop a complete suite of solutions revolving around the Miracast stack - a WiFi Alliance standard allowing wireless HD display through a WiFi network. 
Screenovate focuses on using the smartphone as the centerpiece in home entertainment, giving users the ability to use the home TV as a second screen - allowing big screen gaming and content consumption, while giving carriers a foothold in the living room. There are many challenges on the way there, starting from using as much HW acceleration as possible for completing low-level tasks through designing the best UX for this new usage scenario.

During my time in Screenovate I
- Led the architecture effort in the transition from a demoable PoC to a product
- Instated work processes and tools in the development team
- Managed the development team through an intensive project aimed at one of Japan's largest carriers
- Researched and evaluated new technologies and platforms
- Wrote lots of platform specific, low-level Android code (as well as some high-level stuff, too)
- Solved some very nasty bugs

At Phonaris we aimed to create a real-time management solution for provisioning, securing and configuring smartphones in an enterprise IT environment. We faced a multitude of different mobile platforms (it was before the great Android takeover), with different administration techniques and abilities.
The large scale, distributed back-end had to consolidate all differences into a streamlined web ui, which allowed real-time telemetry and control of single and grouped devices, hiding complexities and platform differences from the IT manager.
At Phonaris I designed and developed the distributed backend, designed the proprietary communication protocol used by on-device agents to communicate with the server and the web front-end for the IT manager.

In this project I implemented a new encryption and authentication module for TI's Wireless LAN embedded driver in the Android and WinMo platforms.
This required understanding a newly released standard, diving into lots of legacy code (mostly Linux kernel driver) and modifying it in the most simple way to achieve the required functionality.

I led a ground-breaking highly technological operational system from inception through architecture, implementation till successful deployment.
Leading 50 people, 20 of which under direct supervision.
